thread.title_full: London Stock Exchange tries to break into futures market

author: Tim Wallace
title: London Stock Exchange tries to break into futures market
text:
London Stock Exchange Group London Stock Exchange tries to break into futures market The LSE and a group of big banks are launching a new effort to challenge the near-monopoly in the multi-trillion dollar interest rate futures market The LSE hopes it can break its rivals' stranglehold on the futures markets Photo: AP Comments 
The London Stock Exchange and a group of banks are launching a derivatives market which they say will boost competition in the industry and cut prices for traders. 
The venture, called CurveGlobal, is expected to start operating in the second quarter of 2016, and will offer futures trading as well as clearing thorugh LCH.Clearnet, which is also part-owned by the LSE . 
It will begin by offering short-term interest rate futures in Euribor and sterling, and long-term UK and German government debt futures. 
Currently the market for short-term interest rate derivatives is dominated by the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange , which is is part of the Intercontinental Exchange Group, while the long-term market is almost entirely transacted on Deutsche Borse’s platform. 
Previous attempts to break these near-monopolies have failed, but the London Stock Exchange hopes to have a better chance this time by launching the trading platform as a joint venture with half a dozen banks. 
Banking giants and key dealers Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Barclays, Citi, Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan and Societe Generale are all investing in the venture, as well as the Chicago Board Options Exchange. 
Together they are putting in £20.5m, while the LSE is investing £9.5m. 
The London Stock Exchange's chief executive Xavier Rolet said the new venture will "provide greater choice to the market as a whole" Photo: REUTERS 
That gives the stock exchange a 31.7pc share of the market, but it plans to sell that down to 25pc by persuading other investors to join in. 
The new venture hopes to crack the market by offering lower costs for traders, for instance by reducing the margin costs – a type of insurance on trades – on clearing for those customers who trade several related products. 
“Rate markets have undergone considerable change in recent years, and market participants are under ever-increasing cost pressures,” said CurveGlobal’s chairman Michael Davie. 
“Customers want to safely manage risk and to maximise efficiency which the compelling combination of CurveGlobal and LCH Clearnet’s portfolio margining will deliver.” 
It could be a very lucrative market for the new platform – millions of futures contracts are traded daily, with a typical value of around £100,000, meaning the flows and exposures involved run into hundreds of trillions of pounds per year.
